questions.question: A cannon fires a ball at 30°. At what other angle will the ball have a higher peak altitude but the same range?
questions.explanation: Complementary angles (30° and 60°) give same range. Higher angle (60°) gives greater height.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level at $v_0 = 25\text{ m/s}$ at $45^\circ$. What is its time to reach maximum height? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A projectile is launched from ground level at $v_0 = 25\text{ m/s}$ at $45^\circ$. What is its horizontal range on level ground? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A ball is kicked from ground level at $v_0 = 20\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $30^\circ$. What is its maximum height above the launch point? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A ball is kicked from ground level at $v_0 = 24\text{ m/s}$ at $50^\circ$. What is its speed just before it lands back at the same height (ignoring air resistance)?
questions.explanation: Speed at landing equals speed at launch (ignoring air resistance): 24 m/s.

questions.question: A projectile is launched at 20 m/s at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. What is its vertical velocity 1.5 s after launch? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A projectile is launched such that $v_{ix} = 15$ m/s and $v_{iy} = 20$ m/s. What is the total time of flight if it lands at the same height? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
Two projectiles are launched with the same speed. Projectile A is at 30° and Projectile B is at 60°. What is the ratio of the maximum height of B to A? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A ball is kicked to a height of 30 m above the ground. Assuming no air resistance, how long did it take it to reach height 20 m on the way down? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $v_{0y} = \sqrt{2gH} = 24.5$ m/s. Time to apex = 2.45 s. Drop 10 m from apex: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = 1.41$ s. Total = 3.86 s.

questions.question: A ball is kicked to a height of 30 m above the ground. Assuming no air resistance, how long did it take it to reach height 20 m on the way up? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
